org.antkar.syn

Class SynParser

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.antkar.syn.SynParser

  • public class SynParser
extends java.lang.Object

    A parser for a particular grammar. Parses a text and returns an Abstract Syntax Tree (AST). The parser uses the GLR algorithm and thus supports any context-free grammars. However, it may fail to parse some ambiguous grammars.

    Example:

     SynParser parser = new SynParser("@E : E '+' T | T; T : INTEGER;");
 SynResult result = parser.parse("E", "1 + 2 + 3");

    Grammar Structure

    The grammar is specified in an adapted EBNF format. It contains a set of nonterminal definitions:

    @Foo : SyntaxExpression1 ;
 Bar : SyntaxExpression2 ;

    A nonterminal definition consists of a nonterminal name and a syntax expression. If "@" character precedes the nonterminal name, that nonterminal is considered a start nonterminal symbol. More than one start nonterminal symbol can be defined in a single grammar.

    Syntax expression consists of one or more alternative productions separated by "|" character:

    Foo : Production1 | Production2 | Production3 ;

    Production is a sequence of syntax elements:

    Foo : Element1 Element2 Element3 ;
    Each element may be associated with an attribute: 
    Foo : attr1=Element1 attr2=Element2 attr3=Element3 ;

    Return Value

    A nonterminal, production or syntax element may return a syntax node. The result value of the parser is the value returned by the start nonterminal. The return value of a nonterminal is the value returned by the production of that nonterminal which matched the input.

    The return value of a production is defined in the following way:

    1. If the production contains no elements, it returns null.
    2. If the production contains one or more elements, and if one of the elements is assigned to a special result attribute, the production returns the value of that element.
    3. If no elements are assigned to the result attribute, but at least one element is assigned to any other attribute, the production returns an ObjectNode with values of attributed elements mapped to corresponding keys.
    4. If no elements are assigned to attributes, and there is only one element which is not a String literal element (see below), the value of that element is returned.
    5. Otherwise, the return value of the production is undefined.

    Syntax Elements

    There are several kinds of syntax elements. Each syntax element has its own notation and returns a particular type of syntax node.

    Name element

    Can be either a name of a nonterminal symbol, or a name of a literal terminal symbol. The syntax of literal terminal symbols is similar to Java, defined in The Java Language Specification, Third Edition. The return value is a ValueNode of a corresponding type. Literal terminal symbols are:

    NameDescriptionText Example
    ID Identifier, a sequence of letters and digits which does not start with a digit. MyVariableName123
    INTEGER Integer number. Can be decimal, hexadecimal or octal. 12345
    0x12EF
    0765
    FLOAT Floating-point number. Can be decimal or hexadecimal. 123.456
    123.4e10
    0xABC.DEFp5
    STRING String literal enclosed in single or double quotes. Can contain escape sequences. 'Hello World!'
    "Hello World!\n"

    String literal element

    A sequence of characters enclosed in single or double quotes. Defines either a custom keyword or a key-character:

    Grammar ExampleMeaning
    "return"Defines a keyword return.
    "+="Defines an operator +=.

    The sequence must be either an identifier (in which case the element defines a keyword), or it must not contain identifier characters (letters, digits, etc.) at all.

    Nested element

    Syntax: ( syntax_expression )

    Has the same effect as the inner expression. Useful for placing a set of alternative productions inside of a single element:

    Nt : 'aaa' ( Foo | Bar ) 'bbb';

    Optional element

    Syntax: ( syntax_expression )?

    Matches zero or one occurrence of the specified syntax expression. Returns either the result of the expression or null.

    Repetition element

    Syntax: ( syntax_expression )*

    Matches zero or more occurrences of the specified syntax expression. Returns an ArrayNode containing nodes returned by inner expressions.

    Syntax: ( syntax_expression : separator_expression )*

    An optional separator expression may be specified. In this case the element matches zero or more occurrences of syntax_expression separated by separator_expression. Examples:

    Grammar ExampleText Example
    (INTEGER)*123 456 789
    (ID : ",")*aaa , bbb , ccc

    Syntax: ( syntax_expression )+
    Syntax: ( syntax_expression : separator_expression )+

    If "+" is used instead of "*" in a repetition element, the element requires at least one occurrence of the expression.

    Constant element

    Syntax: < constant_value >

    The element matches nothing in the text, but returns a value that can be associated with a syntax tree attribute. Possible values are:

    ExampleDescriptionReturns
    <12345>Integer valueValueNode of integer type
    <123.456> Floating-point value ValueNode of floating-point type
    <"Hello!">String valueValueNode of string type
    <true> true boolean value ValueNode of boolean type
    <false> false boolean value ValueNode of boolean type
    <null>null valuenull
    <java.lang.Thread.NORM_PRIORITY> Value of a Java class static field ValueNode of either the corresponding type or of the object type

    • Method Detail

      • parse

        public SynResult parse(java.lang.String startNonterminal,
                       java.io.Reader textReader)
                throws SynException

        Parses the specified text starting with the specified nonterminal. The text is read from the specified Reader.

        This method is thread-safe, meaning that different inputs can be safely parsed concurrently by the same parser instance. However, this method should not be called concurrently with setFailOnAmbiguity(boolean); in such case it is undefined whether the parser will take the option into account.

        If an ambiguity is detected and the fail-on-ambiguity option is turned on, SynAmbiguityException is thrown. Otherwise, the parser chooses one of conflicting syntax trees and declines the others. The survivor tree is chosen in a way that correctly solves the dangling-else ambiguity, though the exact algorithm of choosing a tree is left undocumented.

        Parameters:
        startNonterminal - the name of the start nonterminal. The nonterminal must be defined in the grammar with a "@" mark.
        textReader - the text reader.
        Returns:
        the Abstract Syntax Tree.
        Throws:
        SynAmbiguityException - if ambiguity is detected, while the fail-on-ambiguity option is on.
        SynException - if parsing fails.

      • parse

        public SynResult parse(java.lang.String startNonterminal,
                       java.io.Reader textReader,
                       SourceDescriptor textDescriptor)
                throws SynException
        Parses the specified text starting with the specified nonterminal. The text is read from the specified Reader. Text source descriptor is specified..
        Parameters:
        startNonterminal - the name of the start nonterminal.
        textReader - the text reader.
        textDescriptor - the text descriptor. Can be null.
        Returns:
        the Abstract Syntax Tree.
        Throws:
        SynException - if parsing fails.
        See Also:
        parse(String, Reader)

      • setFailOnAmbiguity

        public void setFailOnAmbiguity(boolean failOnAmbiguity)
        Sets the fail-on-ambiguity option. When the value is true, the parser throws SynAmbiguityException if it detects an ambiguity. The option is false by default.
        Parameters:
        failOnAmbiguity - the value of the option.

      • createTokenStream

        public org.antkar.syn.internal.scanner.DefaultTokenStream createTokenStream(java.io.Reader reader,
                                                                            SourceDescriptor textDescriptor)
                                                                     throws SynException
        Creates a token stream for the specified input. Except syntax analysis, the returned stream may be useful also for such tasks as syntax coloring, since it can recognize keywords and key-characters defined in the grammar.
        Parameters:
        textDescriptor - the text descriptor. Can be null.
        reader - the text reader.
        Returns:
        the token stream.
        Throws:
        SynException - if stream reading fails.
